{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=June 2017}} {{one source|date=June 2017}} {{BLP primary sources|date=June 2017}} }} {{Infobox economist | name = Costas Meghir | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = [[Greece|Greek]] and [[United Kingdom|British]] | citizenship = | spouse = | website = | institution = [[Yale University]]
[[University College London]] | field = | school_tradition = | alma_mater = [[University of Manchester]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Leonard Gill]] and [[Ian Walker (economist)|Ian Walker]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | influences = | influenced = | contributions = | awards = | memorials = | repec_prefix = | repec_id = | module = | signature = | notes = }} '''Konstantinos''' "'''Costas'''" '''Meghir''' ({{lang-el|Κωνσταντίνος (Κώστας) Εκτώρ Δημήτριος Μεγήρ}}, transcr. ''Konstantinos Ektor Dimitrios Meghir'', born February 13, 1959){{Cite web|url=http://economics.yale.edu/people/costas-meghir|title=Costas Meghir, Department of Economics, Yale University|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} is a [[Greece|Greek]]/[[United Kingdom|British]] [[economist]]. He studied at the [[University of Manchester]] where he graduated with a Ph.D. in 1985, following an MA in economics (with Distinction) in 1980 and a BA (with Honors) in [[Economics]] and [[Econometrics]] in 1979. In 1997 he was awarded the Bodosakis foundation prize and in 2000 he was awarded the “[[Frisch Medal|Ragnar Frisch Medal]]” for his article “Estimating Labour Supply Responses using Tax Reforms” ([[Econometrica]], 1998, Vol. 66, No. 4, with [[Richard Blundell]] and [[Alan S. Duncan|Alan Duncan]]).{{Cite journal|last=Blundell|first=Richard|last2=Duncan|first2=Alan|last3=Meghir|first3=Costas|date=1998|title=Estimating Labor Supply Responses Using Tax Reforms|jstor=2999575|journal=Econometrica|volume=66|issue=4|pages=827–861|doi=10.2307/2999575}} Following his Ph.D. he was appointed at [[University College London]], where he was promoted to Professor in 1993 and was Head of Department of Economics from 2005-2008. He has been at [[Yale University]] since 2010, where he is the “[[Douglas A. Warner III]]” Professor of Economics. He is also a Research Associate of the [[National Bureau of Economic Research|NBER]], a Research Fellow of the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] (IFS) in the UK, a Fellow of the [[British Academy]] (FBA), a Fellow of the [[Econometric Society]], and a Fellow of the Society for Labor Economists. He holds affiliations with [[IZA Institute of Labor Economics|IZA]] and the [[Centre for Economic Policy Research|CEPR]]. He has been co-editor of [[Econometrica]] (2001-2006), joint managing editor of the [[The Economic Journal|Economic Journal]] (1996-2001) and Assistant Editor at the [[The Review of Economic Studies|Review of Economics Studies]] (1990-1994). He is currently editing [[Economics Letters]]. His main research interests are in [[Labour economics|Labor economics]], [[Human capital|Human Capital]], the Economics of the Household and the design of [[tax]] and [[Welfare|welfare programs]]. He has been involved in the evaluation of numerous [[public policy]] programs in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and [[Developing country|developing countries]], including [[Colombia]], [[Chile]] and [[Senegal]]. Recently he has been working in the field of [[child development]]. He has been involved in designing scalable [[Early childhood intervention|Early Childhood interventions]] based on both home visiting and village playgroups in deprived communities. These have been implemented in [[Colombia]] and [[India]] ([[Odisha]]), and evaluated by [[Randomized controlled trial|Randomised Control Trials]] (RCTs). ==Publications== Meghir has over 136 articles on subjects ranging from [[Labor Economics]], [[Education]], [[Child development]], [[Impact evaluation]], Advanced [[Econometrics]], etc.{{Cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/costasmeghir/home|title=Costas Meghir, personal site|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * http://www.ifs.org.uk/people/profile/54 * https://web.archive.org/web/20100907033502/http://www.econ.yale.edu/faculty1/meghir.htm * http://www.ucl.ac.uk/economics/people/academic/meghir * [http://dailybulletin.yale.edu/article.aspx?id=7814 Costas Meghir appointed the first Douglas A. Warner III Professor]. [[Yale University]] Daily Bulletin, September 30, 2010. Retrieved 2010-12-22. {{Frisch Medal recipients}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Meghir, Costas}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Greek economists]] [[Category:Labor economists]] [[Category:Education economists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Fellows of the British Academy]] [[Category:Fellows of the Econometric Society]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Sign advising not to feed the animals.jpg|right|thumb|Signs such as this are used to emphasize a no-feeding policy]] The prohibition "'''do not feed the animals'''" reflects a policy forbidding the artificial feeding of wildlife ([[wildlife|wild]] or [[Feral organism|feral]] animals) in situations where the animals, or the people doing the feeding, might be harmed. [[Signage|Signs]] displaying this message are commonly found in [[zoo]]s, [[circus]]es, [[animal theme park]]s, [[aquarium]]s, [[national park]]s, [[park]]s, [[public space]]s, [[farm]]s, and other places where people come into contact with [[wildlife]].<ref>Nigel Rothfels, ''Savages and Beasts: The Birth of the Modern Zoo'', JHU Press, 2008, {{ISBN|0801898099}}, p. 35.</ref><ref name="Zoo"/><ref>{{cite journal |title=Do Not Feed the Animals: Do Not Touch: Desire for Wild Animal Companionship in the Twenty-first Century |first=June |last=Dwyer |pages=623-644 |year=2013 |volume=19 |issue=4 |journal=Interdisciplinary Studies in Literature and Environment |doi=10.1093/isle/iss118}}</ref> In some cases there are laws to enforce such no-feeding policies.<ref>NOAA Public Affairs, [http://www.publicaffairs.noaa.gov/releases2004/jan04/noaa04-piro03.html DO NOT FEED OR INTERACT WITH HAWAIIAN MONK SEALS], 30 January 2004, accessed 24 June 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://fwp.mt.gov/news/newsReleases/fishAndWildlife/nr_0483.html |title=Artificial Feeding of Wildlife is against the law |author=Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks |format= |pages= |date=January 29, 2013 |accessdate=2013-06-30 |quote= |publisher=State of Montana }}</ref> However, some people (such as some of those who enjoy feeding pigeons in cities) openly and strongly oppose such laws claiming that animals such as pigeons can be an amenity for people who do not have company such as friends or family, and say that the laws prohibiting feeding animals in urban places must change.<ref>https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/lonely-woman-must-pay-2300-7426683</ref> In some countries, such as [[Greece]], feeding the pigeons in cities is a widespread practice.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3qERMr-ADaY</ref> Cultural hostility to feeding animals in cities and laws that ban the practice raise concerns about how humans relate to other living beings in the urban environment.<ref name="unple">http://unpleasant.pravi.me/unpleasant-for-pigeons/</ref> Politicians have also protested laws that ban feeding feral pigeons in cities.<ref name="unple" /> Feral pigeons in cities existed for thousands of years but only recently in some countries humans started seeing them as a nuisance and became hostile to them.<ref name="pdf">http://www.environment.as.nyu.edu/docs/IO/8744/socialproblems.pdf</ref> In [[India]], feeding feral animals in cities is considered a noble act.<ref>http://www.hindustantimes.com/columns/why-feed-pigeons-dogs-or-monkeys-in-public-places/story-XGbCyMBVsgZL4DECVSfuJN.html</ref> Academicians say that how humans treat animals is related to how humans treat each other and thus raise concerns about the cultural shift from seeing feral city pigeons as harmless in the 1800s to seeing them a undesirable in some countries in the 2000s.<ref name="pdf" />
[[File:No Feeding.jpg|thumb|right|This sign discourages feeding coyotes, which can result in [[Coyote attacks on humans|aggressive behavior]] toward humans<ref name="UrbanCarnivores"/><ref name="AOH"/>]] In zoos, giving food to the animals is discouraged due to the strict [[Diet (nutrition)|dietary controls]] in place.<ref name="Zoo">Darill Clements, ''Postcards from the Zoo'', HarperCollins Australia, 2010.</ref> More generally, artificial feeding can result in, for example, [[Avitaminosis|vitamin deficiencies]]<ref name="DEHP-QLD">{{cite web |url=http://www.ehp.qld.gov.au/wildlife/livingwith/feeding_native_animals.html |title=Feeding native animals |author= |format= |pages= |date=2011 |accessdate=2013-06-30 |quote= |publisher=Queensland Government }}</ref> and [[dietary mineral]] deficiencies.<ref name="Heiser">{{cite web|url=http://www.dgif.virginia.gov/habitat/wild-in-the-woods/feeding-wildlife-food-for-thought.pdf |title=Feeding Wildlife: Food for Thought |author=Carol A. Heiser |format= |pages= |date= |accessdate=2013-07-06 |quote= |publisher=Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521130050/http://www.dgif.virginia.gov/habitat/wild-in-the-woods/feeding-wildlife-food-for-thought.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-21 |df= }}</ref> Another motivation is the concern that animals will become accustomed to ingesting foreign objects and might later ingest something harmful.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cv.vic.gov.au/stories/melbourne-zoo-and-you-150-years/13234/feeding-the-animals/ |title=Feeding the animals |author= |format= |pages= |date=2010 |accessdate=2013-06-24 |quote= |publisher=State of Victoria }}</ref> Outside zoos, a concern is that the increase in local concentrated wildlife population due to artificial feeding can promote the [[Zoonosis|transfer of disease]] among animals or between animals and humans.<ref name="DEHP-QLD"/><ref>{{cite news |author=Alex Cukan |coauthors= |title='Do not feed wild animals' |url=http://www.upi.com/Science_News/2002/08/31/Do-not-feed-wild-animals/UPI-67221030797458/ |quote= |pages= |work=UPI Science News |location= |date=August 31, 2002 |accessdate=2013-06-29 }}</ref> Feeding can also alter animal behavior so that animals routinely travel in larger groups, which can make disease transmission between animals more likely.<ref>Frederick R. Adler and Colby J. Tanner, ''Urban Ecosystems: Ecological Principles for the Built Environment'', Cambridge University Press, 2013, {{ISBN|0521769841}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=qcl_cmlQWkEC&pg=PA210 p. 210.]</ref> In public spaces, the congregation of animals caused by feeding can result in them being considered [[Pest (animal)|pests]].<ref name="UrbanHabitats"/> Artificial feeding can also lead to animals aggressively seeking out food from people, sometimes resulting in injury.<ref name="UrbanCarnivores"/>
==Zoos== [[File:Feeding goats (zoo d'Attilly).jpg|right|thumb|Where zoos permit visitors to feed animals, it is usually domestic animals such as sheep and goats,<ref name="Rees"/> as in this French zoo]] [[Zoo]]s generally discourage visitors from giving any food to the animals.<ref name="Zoo"/> Some zoos, particularly [[petting zoo]]s, do the opposite and actively encourage people to get involved with the feeding of the animals.<ref name="Kleiman">Devra G. Kleiman, Katerina V. Thompson, and Charlotte Kirk Baer, ''Wild Mammals in Captivity: Principles and Techniques for Zoo Management'', 2nd ed., University of Chicago Press, 2010, {{ISBN|0226440117}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=a1vev5hf7o8C&pg=PA140 p. 140.]</ref> This, however, is strictly monitored and usually involves set food available from the [[zookeeper]]s or vending machines, as well as a careful choice of which animals to feed, and the provision of hand-washing facilities to avoid spreading disease.<ref name="Rees">Paul A. Rees, ''An Introduction to Zoo Biology and Management'', Wiley, 2011, [https://books.google.com/books?id=fRp4zrPgTYQC&pg=PT306 p. 306.]</ref> Domestic animals such as [[sheep]] and [[goat]]s are often permitted to be fed,<ref name="Rees"/> as are [[giraffe]]s.<ref name="Kleiman"/>
==National and state parks== [[File:Yogi Bear with "don't feed the bears" message - NARA - 286013.jpg|left|upright|thumb|In the 1960s, US national parks began to discourage the feeding of bears,<ref name="Lau"/> as reflected in this photograph from 1961, featuring [[Yogi Bear]]]] [[File:Safety instructions on Lone Ranch Beach.JPG|thumb|200px|Prohibited activities and safety instructions at a state park in [[Oregon]]]] In [[national park]]s and [[state park]]s, feeding animals can result in malnourishment due to inappropriate diet and in disruption of natural hunting or food-gathering behavior. It can also be dangerous to the people doing the feeding.<ref name="LGE">Lisa Gollin Evans, ''Outdoor Family Guide: Rocky Mountain National Park'', The Mountaineers Books, 2011, [https://books.google.com/books?id=NQSVFNya4jgC&pg=PA23 p. 23.]</ref>
In the US, early 20th century [[Wildlife management|park management]] actually encouraged animal feeding. For example, "the feeding of squirrels had been seen as a way to civilize the parks and rechannel the energies of young boys from aggression and vandalism toward compassion and charity."<ref name="EBenson">{{cite journal |url=http://jah.oxfordjournals.org/content/100/3/691.full |title=The Urbanization of the Eastern Gray Squirrel in the United States | last =Benson | first =Etienne |authorlink= | journal =Journal of American History | volume =100 | issue =3 | pages =691-710 |date =December 2013 |doi = 10.1093/jahist/jat353 |accessdate=2013-12-14 |quote= |work= }}</ref> Park rangers once fed bears in front of crowds of tourists.<ref name="Keiter"/> However, with a greater awareness of ecological and other issues, such pro-feeding policies are now viewed as detrimental,<ref name="Lau">Tammy Lau and Linda Sitterding, ''Yosemite National Park in Vintage Postcards'', Arcadia Publishing, 2000, [https://books.google.com/books?id=eHUuNJT1IGsC&pg=PA125 p. 125.]</ref><ref name="EBenson"/><ref name="Keiter">Robert B. Keiter, ''To Conserve Unimpaired: The Evolution of the National Park Idea'', Island Press, 2013, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Rx-uo4Erq6EC&pg=PA176 p. 176.]</ref><ref>Robert W. Sandford, ''Ecology and Wonder in the Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks World Heritage Site'', Athabasca University Press, 2009, [https://books.google.com/books?id=2aPnUlT5HAkC&pg=PA284 pp. 284–288.]</ref> and US national parks now actively discourage animal feeding.<ref>David Williams, "Conspicuous Consumption," ''National Parks'', April/May 2002, pp. 40–45.</ref>
In Canadian national parks, it is illegal to disturb or feed wildlife,<ref>Terry Inigo-Jones, ''The Canadian Rockies Colourguide'', James Lorimer, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=v9rrvssw1oEC&pg=PA54 p. 54.]</ref> and [[Parks Canada]] advises visitors not to leave out "food attractants" such as dirty dishes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/pn-np/ab/jasper/visit/securite-safety.aspx#conflict |title=Jasper National Park: Safety and Hazards |author=Parks Canada |accessdate=2013-09-29 }}</ref> Ironically, the "it is unlawful to feed animals" signs may themselves become food attractants for [[porcupine]]s.<ref>Kevin Van Tighem, ''Wild Animals of Western Canada'', Rocky Mountain Books, 2009, [https://books.google.com/books?id=w-Nj4mcsR6EC&pg=PA32 p. 32.]</ref> [[Road salt]] and [[roadkill]] may also act as food attractants, and removing roadkill is considered good park management.<ref>Jon P. Beckmann, Anthony P. Clevenger, Marcel Huijser, and Jodi A. Hilty, ''Safe Passages: Highways, Wildlife, and Habitat Connectivity'', Island Press, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=dgiq9UnHVf4C&pg=PA68 p. 68.]</ref>
==Marine parks== [[File:Monkey Mia, Western Australia.jpg|right|thumb|At [[Monkey Mia]] in Australia, [[dolphin]]s are fed under [[Park ranger|ranger]] supervision<ref name="sharkbay">{{cite web|url=http://www.sharkbay.wa.gov.au/visitors/places-to-go/monkey-mia-reserve.html |title=Monkey Mia Reserve |author=Shire of Shark Bay |accessdate=2013-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005020112/http://www.sharkbay.wa.gov.au/visitors/places-to-go/monkey-mia-reserve.html |archivedate=2013-10-05 |df= }}</ref>]] Tourism operators often provide food to attract marine wildlife such as [[Shark tourism|sharks]] to areas where they can be more easily viewed. Such a practice is controversial, however, because it can create a dependency on artificial feeding, habituate animals to feeding locations, increase inter-species and intra-species aggression, and increase the spread of disease.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Higham|first1=James|last2=Lück|first2=Michael |title=Marine Wildlife and Tourism Management: Insights from the Natural and Social Sciences|year=2008|publisher=CAB International|isbn=978-1-84593-345-6|page=58|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TsRZW0dU-6MC&pg=PA58}}</ref> In Australia's [[Great Barrier Reef Marine Park]], shark feeding is prohibited.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kurrawa.gbrmpa.gov.au/corp_site/info_services/publications/sotr/sharks_rays/response.html |title=Environmental Status: Sharks and rays: Response: tourism |author=Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority |accessdate=2013-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110411143054/http://kurrawa.gbrmpa.gov.au/corp_site/info_services/publications/sotr/sharks_rays/response.html |archivedate=2011-04-11 |df= }}</ref> In [[Hawaii|Hawaiian waters]], shark feeding is permitted only in connection with traditional [[Hawaiian religion|Hawaiian cultural or religious activities]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csc.noaa.gov/legislativeatlas/lawDetails.jsp?lawID=568 |title=Prohibition of Shark Feeding |author=Hawaii Department of Land and Natural Resources, Hawaii Department of Agriculture |accessdate=2013-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140820061233/http://www.csc.noaa.gov/legislativeatlas/lawDetails.jsp?lawID=568 |archivedate=2014-08-20 |df= }}</ref>
The feeding of wild [[dolphin]]s for tourist purposes is also controversial, and is prohibited in the US because it can alter natural hunting behaviour, disrupt social interaction, encourage the dolphins to approach or ingest dangerous objects, and endanger the person doing the feeding.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gales |first1=Nicholas |last2=Hindell |first2=Mark |last3=Kirkwood |first3=Roger | title=Marine Mammals: Fisheries, Tourism and Management Issues |year=2003|publisher=[[CSIRO]] |isbn=0643099263 |page=306 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QkLGVQDvN7MC&pg=PA306 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/pr/education/protectdolphins.htm |title=Protect Dolphins Campaign |author=[[National Marine Fisheries Service]] |accessdate=2013-07-19 }}</ref> At [[Monkey Mia]] in Western Australia, dolphin feeding is permitted under [[Department of Environment and Conservation (Western Australia)|Department of Environment and Conservation]] supervision.<ref name="sharkbay"/>
==Backyards== Similar issues to those in national and state parks also apply in suburban and rural [[backyard]]s. Artificial feeding of [[coyote]]s, deer, and other wildlife is discouraged.<ref name="UrbanCarnivores">Stanley D. Gehrt, Seth P. D. Riley, and Brian L. Cypher, ''Urban Carnivores: Ecology, Conflict, and Conservation'', JHU Press, 2010, {{ISBN|0801893895}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=xYKqluO6c8UC&pg=PA231 p. 231.]</ref><ref name="AOH">{{cite web| title = Coyote Attacks: An Increasing Suburban Problem|url = http://www.co.san-diego.ca.us/awm/docs/coyoteattacks.pdf|accessdate =August 19, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926044522/http://www.co.san-diego.ca.us/awm/docs/coyoteattacks.pdf |archivedate = September 26, 2007}}</ref><ref name="Coyote">Stephen DeStefano, ''Coyote at the Kitchen Door: Living With Wildlife in Suburbia'', Harvard University Press, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=qqo0Po4xSwAC&pg=PA76 p. 76.]</ref> Feeding deer, for example, may contribute to the spread of [[Mycobacterium bovis|bovine tuberculosis]].<ref name="Heiser"/> The feeding of birds with [[bird feeder]]s is an exception, at least in the US, even though it can sometimes contribute to spreading disease.<ref name="Coyote"/><ref>Tom Warhol and Marcus Schneck, ''Birdwatcher's Daily Companion: 365 Days of Advice, Insight, and Information for Enthusiastic Birders'', Quarry Books, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YkepQQWk-TQC&pg=PA7 p. 7.]</ref><ref>John W. Fitzpatrick and André A. Dhondt, "[http://www.birds.cornell.edu/Publications/Birdscope/Spring2003/In_Defense.html In Defense of Bird Feeding]," ''Birdscope, newsletter of the Cornell Lab of Ornithology'', Spring 2003.</ref> In Australia, artificial [[bird feeding]] is viewed more negatively.<ref name="DEHP-QLD"/> Instead, growing native plants that can act as a natural food source for birds is recommended.<ref name="DEHP-QLD"/> Similar suggestions have been made in the US.<ref name="Heiser"/>
==Public spaces== [[File:Do not feed the pigeons.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Sign in Singapore telling people not to feed the pigeons]] [[File:Man feeding pigeons.jpg|thumb|right|[[Feral pigeon]]s being fed in a public space]] [[File:Do not feed our ducks - geograph.org.uk - 942538.jpg|thumb|right|Sign telling citizens to not feed the ducks<ref name="Erickson"/>]] [[Feral pigeon]]s are often found in urban [[public space]]s. They are often considered environmental pests, and can transmit diseases such as [[psittacosis]].<ref name="UrbanHabitats">C. Philip Wheater, ''Urban Habitats'', Routledge, 2002, {{ISBN|0203061144}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GeVUjqkWx60C&pg=PA94 p. 94.]</ref> Deliberate feeding of feral pigeons, though popular, contributes to these problems.<ref name="UrbanHabitats"/>
[[Duck]]s are also commonly fed in public spaces. In one US study, 67% of people visiting urban parks did so to feed ducks.<ref>Thomas G. Barnes, ''Gardening for the Birds'', University Press of Kentucky, 1999, {{ISBN|0813129028}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=jVQEVh0ZD1EC&pg=PA9 p. 9.]</ref> However, such feeding may contribute to water pollution and to over-population of the birds, as well as delaying [[Bird migration|winter migration]] to an extent that may be dangerous for the birds.<ref name="Erickson">Laura Erickson, ''101 Ways to Help Birds'', Stackpole Books, 2006, {{ISBN|0811733025}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=m6SrsYLQ_V0C&pg=PA130 p 130.]</ref> Feeding foods such as white bread to ducks and geese can result in bone deformities.<ref name="Heiser"/> Like pigeons, ducks may also congregate in large numbers where feeding takes place, resulting in aggression towards humans who don't have food to hand as well as towards other individuals in the group. Ducks can also be messy animals, and the cleanup of an area where they congregate is time consuming.
==See also== * [[Protected area]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox University |name = English Nanny & Governess School |image = English Nanny and Governess School Logo.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = |motto = ''Education Begins at Birth'' |established = 1984 |type = [[Private school|Private]], [[non profit]] |affiliation = |president = Sheilagh Roth |city = [[Chagrin Falls]] |state = [[Ohio]] |country = [[United States]] |students = |staff = |campus = |former_names = |nickname = ENGS |fightsong = |athletics = |colors = Turquoise and brown {{color box|#b9d3d0}} {{color box|#605749}} |website = http://www.nanny-governess.com/ |logo = }} '''English Nanny & Governess School (ENGS)''', founded in 1984 by Sheilagh Roth<ref name="Chagrin Solon Sun">{{cite web|url=http://www.nanny-governess.com/images/NLArticle.pdf|title=Ready For Prime Time|publisher=Chagrin Solon Sun}}</ref> provides childcare education and training. Graduates of English Nanny & Governess School are employed in the [[United States]] and around the world as [[nanny|nannies]] and [[governess]]es.<ref name= "The Wealth Report:The Wall Street Journal">{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/wealth/2011/08/22/the-200000-a-year-nanny/|title=The $200,000-a-Year Nanny|publisher=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
English Nanny & Governess School was originally located on the campus of [[Case Western Reserve University]], in [[Cleveland, Ohio]]. It was relocated to [[Chagrin Falls, Ohio]] in 1992.
The school is licensed by the Ohio State Board of Career Colleges and Schools.
The curriculum consists of a three-month classroom instruction program that is accompanied by an in-home practicum program. Upon completion, graduates are awarded the title of "certified professional nanny" or "certified professional governess," through the American Council of Nanny Schools (ACNS).<ref name= "American Council of Nanny Schools">{{cite web|url=http://www.americancouncilofnannyschools.com/|title=American Council of Nanny Schools|publisher=American Council of Nanny Schools}}</ref>
==History== The school was founded in 1984, on the grounds of Case Western Reserve University. In 1992, it moved to its current location in the village of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The school was the first of its kind in America, with a full academic faculty dedicated exclusively to educating nannies and governesses.<ref name="Everyday Health">{{cite web|url=http://www.everydayhealth.com/kids-health/finding-the-best-nanny-for-your-kids.aspx|title=Finding the Best Nanny for Your Kids|publisher=Everyday Health}}</ref>
The school was invited to represent the child-care and nanny profession at the Conference on Childcare at [[The White House]], by the [[First Lady]], [[Hillary Clinton]].
The school has appeared in newspaper and magazine articles, including ''[[The Times of London]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', and ''[[W (magazine)|W]]'', as well as radio shows, and on television programs. The television shows include ''[[Good Morning America]]'', ''[[Fox News]]'', ''[[Larry King Live]]'' and ''[[Nightline]]''.<ref name="English Nanny and Governess School:Media">{{cite web|url=http://www.nanny-governess.com/media.html|title=Media|publisher=English Nanny & Governess School}}</ref><ref name="Sun News">{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/chagrinsolonsun/index.ssf/2011/06/abc_nightline_visits_english_n.html|title=ABC "Nightline" visits English Nanny and Governess School in Chagrin Falls|publisher=Cleveland.com}}</ref><ref name="The New York Times">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/13/nyregion/13bigcity.html?_r=0|title=Much Is Asked, Little Defined for the Nanny|publisher=The New York Times}}</ref>
==Academics== The school offers a three-month course in the fields of <ref name="Cleveland Scene">{{cite web|url=http://www.nanny-governess.com/images/SceneMag2.pdf|title=Paging Mary Poppins|publisher=Cleveland Scene Magazine}}</ref> child growth, behavior and development, experiential education<ref name="W Magazine">{{cite web|url=http://www.nanny-governess.com/images/WENGSart.pdf|title=Les Efants Terribles|publisher=W Magazine}}</ref> childcare, cultural enrichment, and personal protection and safety, as well as professionalism. Students must complete a minimum of 300 course hours.<ref name="English Nanny and Governess School:Curriculum">{{cite web|url=http://www.nanny-governess.com/home/courselisting.html|title=The Distinguished Curriculum at ENGS|publisher=English Nanny & Governess School}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.americancouncilofnannyschools.com/ *http://www.nanny-governess.com/home.html *http://scr.ohio.gov/
{{DEFAULTSORT:English Nanny and Governess School}} [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1984]] [[Category:Companies based in Ohio]] [[Category:Companies based in Cleveland]] [[Category:Child care skills organizations]] [[Category:1984 establishments in Ohio]]

{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Frederick John Kiesler | image = F. Kiesler 1.jpg | imagesize = 180px | caption = ''F. Kiesler at the'' Internationale Ausstellung neuer Theatertechnik, ''Vienna''. 1924. | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1890|9|22|}} | birth_place = [[Chernivtsi]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1965|12|27|1890|9|22|}} | death_place = [[New York City]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | field = [[Architect]], [[Designer]] | training = | movement = | works = [[Shrine of the Book]] (1957–65) | patrons = | influenced by = [[Adolf Loos]], [[De Stijl]] | influenced = | awards = }} '''Frederick John Kiesler''' ([[Czernowitz]] or Tschernovitz, [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]] (now [[Chernivtsi]], [[Ukraine]]), September 22, 1890 – [[New York City]], December 27, 1965) (born as Friedrich Jacob Kiesler). [[Austria]]n-[[United States|American]] architect, theoretician, theater designer, artist and sculptor. ==Biography== From 1908 to 1909, Kiesler studied at the [[Vienna University of Technology|Technische Hochschule]] in [[Vienna]]. From 1910–12, he attended painting and printmaking classes at the [[Akademie der bildenden Künste]], both in [[Vienna]]. In July 1913, Kiesler quit the academy without having earned a diploma. He married Stefanie (Stefi) Frischer (1896–1963) in 1920, and they moved to New York City in 1926, where he lived until his death. Kiesler collaborated there early on with the [[Surrealists]], and with [[Marcel Duchamp]]. His writing was extensive, and his theoretical work embraced two lengthy manifestos, the article "Pseudo-Functionalism in Modern Architecture" (''[[Partisan Review]]'', July 1949) and the book ''Contemporary Art Applied to the Store and Its Display'' (New York: Brentano, 1930). Stefi Kiesler died in September 1963. In 1964, the year before his death, Kiesler married Lillian Olinsey, his longtime secretary and confidante, as Stefi had advised him to do while she was still living. In May 1965, he traveled to Jerusalem for the inauguration of the [[Shrine of the Book]]; seven months later he died in New York City. ==Design and architectural career== Kiesler was productive as a theater and art-exhibition designer in the 1920s in Vienna and [[Berlin]]. In 1920, he started a brief collaboration with architect [[Adolf Loos]] and, in 1923, became a member of the [[De Stijl]] group in 1923. Kiesler was friendly with many of the major figures of the European [[avant-garde]], which may have influenced his heretical approach to artistic theories and practices. Kiesler arranged the world premiere in Vienna on September 24, 1924, of the 16-minute film ''[[Ballet mécanique]]'', directed by [[Dudley Murphy]] and [[Fernand Léger]], with [[Man Ray]]. In November 1975, Lillian Kiesler, Frederick's second wife, found Léger's original spliced [[35mm]], 16-minute version of the film in the closet of their week-end house in the [[Hamptons]] on [[Long Island]], near New York City. This version, restored by [[Anthology Film Archives]], has since been included in the documentary film compilation ''Unseen Cinema: Early American Avant-Garde Film 1893-1941'' (released as a seven-disc DVD set by Image Entertainment, October 2005). The music for the film was originally composed by [[George Antheil]], who used it to create a separate concert piece, also named ''Ballet mécanique'', which premiered in Paris in 1926. His architectural designs include the [[Film Guild Cinema]] (1929) in New York City and, with [[Armand Phillip Bartos]], the [[Shrine of the Book]] (1965) in [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]].Jacobson, Samuel. [http://www.archdaily.com/156442/AD "Classics: Shrine of the Book / Armand Phillip Bartos and Frederick John Kiesler"], ''ArchDaily'', September 24, 2011, accessed October 7, 2014 From 1937 to 1943, Kiesler was the director of the Laboratory for Design Correlation within the [[Columbia Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation|Department of Architecture]] at [[Columbia University]], where the study program was more pragmatic and commercially oriented than his deep, theoretical concepts and ideas, such as those about "correalism" or "continuity," which concern the relationship among space, people, objects and concepts.Thomas Creighton (July 1961), "Kiesler's Pursuit of an Idea," ''[[Progressive Architecture]]'', vol. 42, no. 7, p. 104 For his object designs, such as the biomorphic furniture in his Abstract Gallery room of [[Peggy Guggenheim]]’s ''[[The Art of This Century Gallery]]'' art salon (1942), for example. For it, he sought to dissolve the visual, real, image, and environment into a free-flowing space. He likewise pursued this approach with his “[[Endless House]],” exhibited in maquette form in 1958–59 at [[The Museum of Modern Art]]. The project stemmed from his shop-window displays of the 1920s and his [[Film Guild Cinema]] in New York City, mentioned above. Pursuing display and art-gallery work, he was a window designer for [[Saks Fifth Avenue]] from 1928 to 1930. Earlier in his career in Europe, Kiesler invented the 1924 L+T (Leger und Trager) radical hanging system for galleries and museums. His unorthodox architectural drawings and plans that he called "polydimensional" were somewhat akin to Surrealist automatic drawings. He designed some intriguing furniture, a few pieces of which were featured in the yearbook of the short-lived [[American Union of Decorative Artists and Craftsmen]] (AUDAC); he was a founding member of the organization in 1930. Some models of the furniture — none of which was reproduced in numbers as intended — have been posthumously manufactured in limited quantities by various firms in Europe since 1990. The most popular has been the cast-aluminum "Two-Part Nesting Table" (1935). ==Galaxies and Installational Works== During the 1950s, Kiesler created a series of paintings called ''Galaxies'', which translated his vision of space into multi-paneled installations that protruded from the wall. Combining painting, sculpture and drawing, the ''Galaxies'' were presented as grouped units. To Kiesler, the space between the different parts was just as important as the paintings themselves, marking a reflection of the “inner necessity” of the work as a whole. He noted that it was the same as what “breathing is to our body reality.” Kiesler wrote further: {{Quote|text=''"Each painting represents a definite unit in itself just as in one family each member is of distinct individuality. Yet, their firm cohesion (into one) is inborn no matter how heterogeneous the character of the members might be. Under these circumstances, it seems natural that each painted unit, particularly when protruding from the wall, and viewed from the side, will also assume the value of a plastic entity, very much in the sense of sculpture, while the aspect of the total galaxy promotes too, the idea of an architectural coordinate without destroying the main character as a painting. Thus the traditional division of the plastic arts, sculpture, and architecture, is transmuted and overcome and their fluid unification is now contained within rather than combined from without."''}} [[File:Frederick Kiesler, Horse Galaxy, 1954, installation view at Jason McCoy Gallery.jpg|thumb|left|Frederick Kiesler, ''Horse Galaxy'', 1954, installation view at Jason McCoy Gallery, 1993.]] These multi-paneled paintings were also sparked by the artist's response to the political and social upheaval of his time. Conceived only a few years after the atomic bombings of [[Hiroshima]] and [[Nagasaki]], Kiesler described his inspiration for the ''Galaxies'' as follows: {{Quote|text=''"If the reassessment of values in these tense times is of necessity for each and all of us, one is convinced that the artist’s work too can no longer be placed in isolation: that art must strive again to become part of daily experience. It seems, therefore, that painters, sculptors, and architects must conceive their work – as part of the world."''}} [[File:Frederick Kiesler, Us, You, Me installation view, Parrish Art Museum.jpg|thumb|Installation view of Frederick Kiesler's ''Us, You, Me'' at the [[Parrish Art Museum]] in 2003. ]] Kiesler’s body of sculptural works also incorporate similar philosophies, uniting individual pieces with specific placements, further illustrating his theories of human-design relationships. His installation of ''Us, You, Me'' (completed 1963-65), included pieces in bronze, aluminum, wood, granite, and concrete in various sizes, and was shown at [[Hunter College]]/Times Square Gallery (2004),{{cite news|last1=Cotter|first1=Holland|title=Art in Review: 'Moved'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/09/arts/art-in-review-moved.html|publisher=The New York Times|date=April 9, 2004}} The [[Parrish Art Museum]] (2003),{{cite web|last1=Longwell|first1=Alicia G.|title=FREDERICK KIESLER: THE LATE WORK US, YOU, ME AUGUST 10 - OCTOBER 12 2003|url=http://artists.parrishart.org/index.php/Detail/Occurrence/Show/occurrence_id/124|website=Parrish Art Museum}} and the [[University of Iowa Museum of Art]] (1995). The idea of sculpture as a landscape in ''Us, You, Me'' reflects upon Kiesler’s history with stage design, and the subject matters marking underlying anxieties of modern life. Kiesler’s final sculpture ''Bucephalus'', inspired by [[Bucephalus|Alexander the Great’s battle horse]], was to be entered by the viewer and used as a grotto for meditation. The sculpture was conceived in concrete and mesh by Kiesler and his assistant, Len Pitkowsky, between 1962-1965 and was posthumously cast in aluminum at the Polich Tallix Foundry, Rock Tavern, New York by [[Jason McCoy Inc|Jason McCoy Gallery]] with the help of Len Pitkowsky between 2006-2008. ==Recognition and awards== Kiesler was often shunned by his peers, although he was chosen in 1952 as one of "the 15 leading artists at mid-century" by The [[Museum of Modern Art]] and in 1957 became a fellow of the Graham Foundation in Chicago. [[Israel]]i architects disapproved of his and Bartos's serving as the architects for the [[Shrine of the Book]] (1957–65) because they were not Israelis, even though they were [[Jews]]. Further objections to Kiesler were that he had not completed his architecture studies and had built no structures, despite having been a licensed architect in [[New York (state)|New York State]] since 1930. One of his colleagues at Columbia University joked: "If Kiesler wants to hold two pieces of wood together, he pretends he's never heard of nails or screws. He tests the tensile strengths of various metal alloys, experiments with different methods and shapes, and after six months comes up with a very expensive device that holds two pieces of wood together almost as well as a screw"."Design's Bad Boy", ''[[Architectural Forum]]'', vol. 86, no. 2, p. 140, February 1947 The Austrian Frederick and Lillian Kiesler Private Foundation was established in 1997 in Vienna and biennially grants the Austrian Frederick Kiesler Prize for Architecture and the Arts. Recipients include [[Hani Rashid]], [[Lise Anne Couture]], [[Andrés Jaque]], [[Toyo Ito]], [[Andrea Zittel]], and [[Judith Barry]].{{cite web|last1=Meissner|first1=Jill|title=Austrian Frederick Kiesler Prize for Architecture and the Arts Laureate 2016 ANDRÉS JAQUE|url=http://www.kiesler.org/cms/media/pdf/KP2016_Presskit_20161007_EN.pdf|website=Austrian Frederick and Lillian Kiesler Private Foundation|date=7 October 2016}} ==Exhibitions== * "Galaxies by Kiesler", [[Sidney Janis Gallery]], New York City, September 27 - October 19, 1954 * "Frederick Kiesler", [[Hochschule für angewandte Kunst in Wien|Hochschule für angewandte Kunst]], Vienna, 1975 * "Friedrich [sic] Kiesler—Visionär, 1890–1965", [[mumok|Museum moderner Kunst]], Vienna, and touring, from 1988 * "Friedrick [sic] Kiesler", [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], New York City, 1989 * Kiesler drawings and reproduction furniture, [[Jason McCoy Inc|Jason McCoy Gallery]], New York City, 1990–91 * "Frederick Kiesler: arte, architettura, ambiente", Milan, Italy, 1995 * "Friederick [sic] Kiesler: artiste-architecte", [[Centre Georges Pompidou]], Paris, July 3-October 21, 1996 * "Frederick J. Kiesler: Endless Space", [[Schindler House#MAK Center for Art and Architecture|MAK Center for Art and Architecture at the Schindler House, Los Angeles]], December 6, 2000 - February 25, 2001 * "Frederick Kiesler: Endless", [[Jason McCoy Inc|Jason McCoy Gallery]], New York City, April 15 - May 3, 2008 * "Frederick Kiesler: Co-Realities", [[Drawing Center]], New York City, 2008 * "Frederick Kiesler: Off the Wall", [[Jason McCoy Inc|Jason McCoy Gallery]], New York City, March 11 – May 1, 2010 * "Die Kulisse explodiert. Friedrich Kiesler und das Theater", [[Österreichisches Theatermuseum]], Vienna, October 25, 2012 - February 25, 2013; traveled to Museum Villa Stuck, Munich, March 20 - June 23, 2013 * "Frederick Kiesler: Life Visions", [[Museum of Applied Arts, Vienna]], 2016 * "Inside the Endless House. Re-Reading Friedrich/Frederick Kiesler", [[Museum of Applied Arts, Vienna|MAK – Österreichisches Museum für angewandte Kunst / Gegenwartskunst]], Vienna, June 15 - September 25, 2016 * "Frederick Kiesler: Galaxies", [[Jason McCoy Inc|Jason McCoy Gallery]], New York City, November 28 - January 28, 2016 * "Friedrich Kiesler:Architect, Artist, Visionary", [[Martin-Gropius-Bau]], Berlin, March 11 - June 11, 2017 ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== {{Empty section|date=October 2014}} The Estate of Frederick Kiesler is represented by [http://jasonmccoygallery.com/kiesler_pg.html Jason McCoy Gallery], New York.

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox school | name = Glenaeon Rudolf Steiner School | image = GlenaeonRudolfSteiner.jpg | motto = ''Unfolding Individual Journeys'' | established = 1957 | type = [[Independent school|Independent]], [[Waldorf education|Steiner Waldorf]], [[Co-education]]al, [[Day school]] | denomination = [[Non-denominational]] | slogan = ''A rich and rigorous education of discovery that respects childhood, builds resilient individuals and celebrates the human spirit.'' | principal = | address = Glenroy Ave | city = [[Middle Cove, New South Wales|Middle Cove]] & [[Castlecrag, New South Wales|Castlecrag]] | state = [[New South Wales]] | country = [[Australia]] | coordinates = {{Coord|-33.7911223|151.2077339|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | enrolment = 500 (K-12)<ref name=Intro>{{cite web |url=http://www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au/about_glenaeon.php |title=Glenaeon |accessdate=2007-08-23 |work=Glenaeon Rudolf Steiner School }}</ref> | staff = 58<ref name=Intro/> | products = | colours = Navy Blue & White | website = {{URL|www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au}} }}
'''Glenaeon Rudolf Steiner School''' is an independent, co-educational day school co- located across multiple campuses in [[Middle Cove, New South Wales|Middle Cove]], [[Castlecrag, New South Wales|Castlecrag]] and [[Willoughby, New South Wales|Willoughby]] in the [[Lower North Shore (Sydney)|Lower North Shore]] of [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]]. It was the first Steiner school established in [[Australia]]. The three campuses include the Pre-School in Willoughby, a Junior School (K-2) at Castlecrag and years 3-12 in Middle Cove.
The school’s curriculum and pedagogy follows the NSW Education Standards Authority requirements,combined with the educational insights of Austrian-born philosopher, scientist, artist and educator Rudolf Steiner (1861-1925). There are now more than 1000 Steiner schools in 61 different countries worldwide and over 40 Steiner schools in Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|title = About Steiner Education Australia - Steiner Education Australia|url = http://www.steinereducation.edu.au/about/|website = www.steinereducation.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-09-17|first = Steiner Education|last = Australia}}</ref>
Kamaroi Rudolf Steiner School (K-6), is located in [[Belrose]] and serves as a feeder school for both Glenaeon and [[Lorien Novalis School]] in Dural.
Glenaeon's motto is "Unfolding Individual Journeys". It was previously "Education for Life".
==History== The school was originally established in Pymble in 1957, by Sylvia Brose OAM, out of the community surrounding Walter and Marion Burley Griffin and their belief that the values of design, the arts, community, nature and spirit needed to underpin a rich academic education.
In 1970 the school was fully established in Middle Cove, located on four and a half acres of bushland. During the 1990s, Glenaeon expanded to the Castlecrag campus, where it now caters for Kindergarten and classes 1 and 2.
==Facilities== The School currently has two halls, the Sylvia Brose Hall at Middle Cove and the Marion Mahony Griffin Hall at Castlecrag. The Middle Cove campus also includes two playing fields, two multipurpose basketball courts, specialist Design & Technology and Art facilities, a biodynamic garden and music rooms. The high school building features several classrooms including a recently renovated library.
== Notable alumni == ;Entertainment, media and the arts * [[John Polson]], [[actor]] and [[film director]]; founder of [[Tropfest]] *[[Toby Thatcher]], [[oboe|oboist]]; [[Sydney Symphony Orchestra]] assistant conductor <ref name="Thatcher">{{cite web | url = http://www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au/where-are-they-now/toby-thatcher | title = Toby Thatcher | work = Where Are They Now? | publisher = Glenaeon Rudolf Steiner School | accessdate = 12 May 2015 }}</ref> * [[Brenna Hobson]], [[theatre director]]; [[National Theatre of Scotland]] executive director and former [[Belvoir Street Theatre]] executive director .<ref>{{Cite web|title = Brenna Hobson|url = http://www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au/where-are-they-now/brenna-hobson|website = www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-09-17}}</ref> *[[Ian (Herbie) Hemphill]],[[chef]] and [[author]] - Australia’s "king of spice" <ref>{{Cite web|title = Ian Hemphill|url = http://www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au/where-are-they-now/ian-hemphill|website = www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-09-17}}</ref> * [[Richard Claremont]], artist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-02-26/painting-postman-creates-art-on-two-wheels/7202776|title=Post and paintings: Wollongong's artist on two wheels|author=Justin Huntsdale|date=February 26, 2016|publisher=[[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC Illawarra]]|accessdate=April 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glenaeon.nsw.edu.au/where-are-they-now/richard-claremont|title=Richard Claremont (1982)|year=2015|publisher=Glenaeon Rudolf Steiner School| accessdate=April 25, 2018}}</ref> * [[Tamlyn Henderson]]; [[actor]] * Hip Hop trio [[Bliss N Eso]] members Jonathan Notley, Max McKinnon, and Tarik Ejjaimai
;Politics, public service and the law * [[James Alexander Gardner|James Gardener]], tech executive; former [[Department for Work and Pensions]] CTO

{{Infobox journal | title = Harvard Educational Review | cover = | editor = | discipline = [[Education]] | abbreviation = Harv. Educ. Rev. | publisher = Harvard Education Publishing Group | country = United States | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1930–present | openaccess = | license = | website = http://hepg.org/her-home/home | LCCN = 34007870 | OCLC = 1587741 | ISSN = 0017-8055 | eISSN = 1943-5045 }} The '''''Harvard Educational Review''''' is an [[academic journal]] of opinion and research dealing with [[education]], associated with the [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]], and published by the Harvard Education Publishing Group. The journal was established in 1930.
Since 1945, editorial decisions have been carried out by an autonomous graduate student [[editorial board]]. This student board works together to bring to publication manuscripts on a wide range of topics and from a number of disciplines.
==Alumni== Notable alumni of the ''Harvard Educational Review'' include: *[[Lisa Delpit]], educationalist and [[MacArthur Fellow]] *[[Sara Lawrence-Lightfoot]], educational sociologist and [[MacArthur Fellow]] *[[Orval Hobart Mowrer]], psychologist and former president of the [[American Psychological Association]] *[[Lauren Resnick]], educational psychologist *[[Ted Sizer|Theodore Sizer]], educationalist and founder of the [[Coalition of Essential Schools]] *[[Julian Stanley]], psychologist and founder of the [[Center for Talented Youth]]
==External links== *{{Official website|http://hepg.org/her-home/home}}
